newsitem.title: GERMANY: German coffee physicals ruled by nearby tightness.
newsitem.headline: German coffee physicals ruled by nearby tightness.

text.p: Firm prices are expected to hold in Germany's physical coffee market as nearby tightness begins to extend into early 1997, traders said on Monday.
"Roasters expecting to fill gaps in their cover for this year find differentials (over futures) prohibitive, if the material is at all available," one trader said.
"Central Americans and Colombians attract high premiums for 1996 and levels have also hardened for early next year."
But traders added there were sufficient Brazils on offer at reasonable prices and good quality to avoid a panic among consumers.
Another factor offsetting the tightness was only average consumption, which was unlikely to change unless the winter got to be extremely harsh.
"If a cold winter lifted coffee consumption above current levels, the supply situation in early 1997 could become quite difficult," one trader said.
"Naturally, all eyes are on the pace of the new crop arrivals."
The physical scenario was in contrast to sharp futures losses in New York arabicas as a result of speculative and producer selling last Friday.
Benchmark December closed at 109.10 cents/lb, off 0.80.
But traders here believed the market may move sideways this week, based on its ability to hold key support at 108.50.
In the Bremen import market, Brazils were offered at $106 per 50 kg fob, down $9 on the week, and Colombia Excelso was at $128, down $6.
Kenyan price fell less sharply to $150 from $156 a week earlier and Indonesian robustas were off $3 at $62.
Roasters bought arabicas for the first half of 1996 but interest in robustas was limited because of the prospect of large Asian crops.
